subsection.title: 2. Find the x-intercepts of a parabola

introduction.p: To solve a quadratic inequality, we first find the x-intercepts of the graph. Remember that there are four different methods for solving a quadratic equation.

statement.p: Find the x-intercepts of the parabola ~y=4x^2-12

solution.p: Set y=0 and solve for x. Use extraction of roots. 4x^2-12 \amp = 0 4x^2 \amp = 12 x^2 \amp = 3 x \amp = \pm \sqrt{3} The x-intercepts are (\sqrt{3},0) and (-\sqrt{3},0), or about (1.7,0) and (-1.7,0).

statement.p: Find the x-intercepts of the parabola ~y=-4x^2-12x

solution.p: Set y=0 and solve for x. Factor the right side. 0 \amp = -4x^2-12x 0 \amp = -4x(x+3) \amp \amp \blert{\text{Set each factor equal to 0.}} 4x\amp = 0~~~~~~x+3 = 0 x \amp = 0~~~~~~x=-3 The x-intercepts are (0,0) and (-3,0).

statement.p: Find the x-intercepts of the parabola ~y=4x^2-12x+8

solution.p: Set y=0 and solve for x. Factor the right side. 0 \amp = 4x^2-12x+8 0 \amp = 4(x^2-3x+2) 0 \amp = 4(x-2)(x-1) \amp \amp \blert{\text{Set each factor equal to 0.}} x-2\amp = 0~~~~~~x-1 = 0 x \amp = 2~~~~~~x=1 The x-intercepts are (2,0) and (1,0).
